resources.string: Press power button to start TLSMetric
TLS Metric service is not yet running
TLSMetric service has been started in passive mode.
TLSMetric service has been stopped. Was in passive mode.

Welcome to Privacy Friendly TLS Metric. 
 
 This app scans active network connections in background. The detected connections are listed with their invoking apps, the remote host (if resolvable) and an identification of the service used. 
 
 Additionally, very detailed technical information can be displayed by touching one of the listed connections. An automatic Certificate Validation and SSL Server Test can be toggled in the setting, allowing TLS Metric to request a Transport Layer Security (TLS) rating of addressed Servers. The ratings are provided by SSL-Labs (), see "help" for further information. 
 
 This App has been developed with privacy in mind, and does not use any unnecessary permissions and does not save or transmit any personal data. For further information see "help" or pick "about" in the navigation.
This "Privacy Friendly" Version of TLSMetric uses minimal permissions and does not store or transmit any data.
On touch of the start button, TLSMetric starts a passive daemon which monitors all ongoing network connections. A background notification will inform you of the ongoing monitoring.
Start service to inspect active connections.
This app belongs to the group of Privacy Friendly Apps developed by Technische Universität Darmstadt. Sourcecode licensed under GPLv3. Images copyright TU Darmstadt und Google Inc.
More information can be found on:
This app uses by Java-SSLLabs-API Björn Roland and Qualis SSL Labs.
What is Privacy Friendly TLS Metric?

Privacy Friendly TLS Metric is an application for monitoring network traffic from installed apps. It scans active network connections with a background service and displays it with additional information concerning network encryption (Transport Layer Security, TLS).

TLS Metric deploys an background service, scanning for active connections once every second. The apps, invoking the connections are identified and are listed with their icon and the amount of remote addresses they are communicating with in a connection overview. The connection overview can be refreshed by swiping down on the display.

Based on a connections remote port, the transport protocol can be identified by "Well Known Port" tables. Based on this information, a warning is given if a connection is known for not having an encryption employed. Note that this is no grantee that the connection uses this protocol, since the assignment port numbers is not enforced.
The hostname assigned to remote address is requested by name resolution. This is done asynchronously in background and may take some seconds.
A detailed mode can be toggled in the settings view. When activated, a scanned connection can be touched to display additional, technical information on the given connection.

An automatic test of the remote servers encryption implementation can be activated in the settings view. When active, remote servers with a resolved hostname are tested automatically, when the connection protocol is known for employing TLS encryption. The server testing is performed by SSL Lab\'s SSL Server Test (). The remote server\'s encryption quality is shown in grades A+ (best) to F (worst). For further information on SSL Lab API see the about view.

Privacy Friendly App Example does not require any root permission to scan active connections. It further does not include any tracking mechanisms or advertisement and comes free of charge. Privacy Friendly TLS Metric is published under GPLv3 license and therefore is free to distribute or extend.

Privacy Friendly App Example does not require any permission for scanning active connections. The Certificate Validation / SSL Server Test feature requires INTERNET permissions to request server test results from Qualys SSL Labs ().

This App serves as a guideline to see the basic design of Privacy Friendly Apps. The sourcecode is available at GitHub. For further explanations have a look at the Privacy Friendly App Guide.\n\nThe welcome screen should introduce the app and the key elements of the start page.
Provides detailed information when tapping a connection in list
Keep detected connections while service is running
TLSMetric tries to perform a Server Test with SSL Labs API, when possible.
